Cost: The development of an innovative assistive technology for the visually impaired may be expensive, and may not be affordable for all users.
User adoption: The success of the new technology will depend on the willingness of visually impaired users to adopt it and integrate it into their daily lives.
Training: The visually impaired may need training on how to use the new technology, which may require additional support and resources.
Accessibility: The new technology may not be accessible to users who have additional disabilities or challenges, such as hearing impairments or mobility difficulties.

Legal issues: The development of an assistive technology may raise legal issues, such as compliance with accessibility standards, intellectual property rights, or liability in case of errors or malfunctions.
